The main reason I bought this game was to enjoy the Medieval Kingdoms 1212AD mods rather than waiting for Total War Medieval 3, which is still uncertain.

Vanilla alone is great, WRE/ERE are a big challenge. The Sassanids were much easier and felt like old-school Total War. DLC like Age of Charlemagne is a good time; it's the closest you can get to Medieval 3 without using mods.

The game is a bit under-optimized, but there's a way to make the game's performance very optimized!
Performance Tips:
1. Task Manager -> Details -> Right Click Attila Exe -> Set Priority to High
2. Disabling a few of the CPU cores the game can use (Task Manager -> Details -> Right Click Attila Exe -> set Affinity -> check enable only CPU 0 -> click OK  -> Then re-enable all of your CPU again after 3 seconds) fixed it though, guarantee!
3. You need to do this every time you load your game on your Total War Attila's main menu screen.

Got this game purely for the Medieval Kingdoms 1212 AD mod and for that it is a superb game - easily better than Medieval Total War 2. I think its probably the best TW game ever made tbh.

There is one campaign, set in 1212 AD obviously, covering many factions. It looks like the modders are planning to make another later era at some point.

Should say I have been playing with just the official MK 1212 AD files on the Steam Workshop, along with the 'MK 1212 Expanded Portraits' mod. No crashes so far.

Can't comment on the vanilla game as I haven't played anything more than the start of the Prologue but that era of the Dark Ages doesn't interest me much so I didn't get the game for that. But overall the game runs nice and smoothly and graphically looks great.

The campaign delivers a strong sense of impending doom, and the mechanics tied to migration and survival add depth that keeps every turn tense and meaningful. That said, the game can feel overwhelming at times, especially for newer players. The AI is occasionally inconsistent, and performance issues‚Äîwhile improved since launch‚Äîcan still pop up during larger battles. Some factions also feel more polished than others.

As a longtime Total War player, I appreciate what Attila tries to accomplish. Its core mechanics have depth, and veterans of the series will likely find rewarding complexity beneath the chaos. However, the game‚Äôs governance and settlement management systems are deeply flawed, and may feel punishing or even alienating‚Äîespecially for newcomers.

Here‚Äôs a breakdown of my experience:

‚úÖ Strengths:

Cavalry feels powerful and decisive, unlike in Rome II, where mounted units often felt underwhelming.

Factions are well-designed and varied, offering meaningful gameplay differences and a moderate degree of religious flexibility.

The modding community is outstanding, delivering high-quality mods that expand, improve, or completely overhaul the game.

‚ùå Weaknesses:

The governance system and public order mechanics lack clarity and balance, making even well-managed provinces feel unstable. It‚Äôs a core system that undermines enjoyment rather than enhancing challenge.

There are too many DLCs, and many feel superficial or unnecessary. Some players may enjoy the added content, but to me, most of it lacks meaningful value.

üéØ Verdict: 7/10

Wow. This is an amazing Total War title. Probably the most fun I've had playing total war tbh.

This game has better rome campaigns than total war rome II. Eastern Rome is especially fun since it's a lot easier to stabilize and build a good economy than the WRE. Various assorted barbarians(franks, goths, danes, etc.) desert despots(sassanids, himyar, tanukhids, etc.),and eastern nomads(huns, white huns) are also available to play if those factions tickle your fancy.

Probably the best aspect of the game is that it's very hard to steamroll your way across the map due to stacking public order, food, sanitation, and religious penalties. Meaning you really have to think hard about where you want to concentrate strength and investment in your empire, and also whether you can feasibly expand into and keep new holdings. Also when playing as Rome, half the map hates your guts and wants to kill you so it really feels more like a fight for survival than a game that you can just autoresolve every battle and do better than you would fighting the battle yourself. (Looking at you Warhammer III!)

Highly recommend to anyone looking to get into Total War. This and Shogun 2 take the cake for the two best historical titles in the series. 10/10

Verily, this game is as honey to my soul. Each hour I do spend therein, each fleeting minute immersed, doth toss my spirit upon a tempest most wild‚Äîa true emotional chariot, careening betwixt the stars and the abyss. It maketh one laugh with mirth, tremble with dread, rage with fury, and weep with deepest sorrow. In one breath, thou art seized by agony and torment, mingled with hatred, despair, and grievous lamentation. In the next, thy heart soareth with joy, emboldened by triumph and radiant hope.

This game unfoldeth a world of endless fancy and possibility. All that mortal life forbiddeth by chains unjust and cruel limitations, here mayst thou pursue without restraint. Lo! Thou canst raise taxes to the very heavens, funneling coin not to the well-being of thy folk, but rather to feed the fires of war. Or mayhap, thou takest to trade, forging pacts with villainous cartels that slither ‚Äòneath the gaze of thine own capital.

Should thy will lean toward virtue, thou mayest craft a realm most noble: a land of justice and equity, where all live in joy, prosperity, and blessed peace. Yet if thine heart be hardened, thou mayest forge a tyranny most bleak, where every second edifice serveth industry or the plough, taxes bite with cruel teeth, and the people live in wretchedness and want.

In sooth, the possibilities stretch beyond mortal reckoning. I could quill countless scrolls in praise of this wondrous creation, yet I shall not. Suffice it to say: I love this game, and would commend it to all with ears to hear and hearts to feel.

negative.review: It has been a while since I played a Total War game, but I feel there is a lot of micromanagement that distracts here. The game punishes rapid expansion as you cannot maintain multiple territories while ensuring enough food and happiness. This leads to revolts where you are fighting rebel armies along with other enemies. Otherwise it just punishes you for existing, as other reviews have said this entry in the series is about sheer survival. Not to mention the Huns, who in similar fashion to Medieval Total War where the Golden Horde (Mongols) are OP, the Huns are OP and always at full strength. This makes for a good challenge, although the Huns do not attack preferentially (except it seems against Romans) and you can make peace with them. Other issue is diplomacy where seemingly at random a faction will declare war on you and refuse negotiations for unknown reasons (except for monetary gifts, which they never refuse). You are always fighting on multiple fronts and attrition is killer while you're out of your territory not camped. Still fun, but you're in for the long haul with any campaign. Building becomes a balancing act to ensure squalor, disease, strife, happiness, food, income all match up - which is impossible...more revolts. Also don't build a shipyard on the African East coast (or anywhere that water channels don't lead to the ocean) because inevitably you will be locked in with no way to get out and have to disband your fleet. I won a minor victory but was confused as it says puppet states and alliances count toward the total provinces toward victory, but I feel that it didn't account for my alliances - however it only counts a full province which is three settlements in combination, so maybe that's why. Bless those that can play each faction's campaign and the DLC all the way through, because barely 60 hours into it and I feel burnt out. I have several other TW titles in my library but it will likely be a few months before I delve back into the series.

It has been a while since I played a Total War game, but I feel there is a lot of micromanagement that distracts here. The game punishes rapid expansion as you cannot maintain multiple territories while ensuring enough food and happiness. This leads to revolts where you are fighting rebel armies along with other enemies. Otherwise it just punishes you for existing, as other reviews have said this entry in the series is about sheer survival. Not to mention the Huns, who in similar fashion to Medieval Total War where the Golden Horde (Mongols) are OP, the Huns are OP and always at full strength. This makes for a good challenge, although the Huns do not attack preferentially (except it seems against Romans) and you can make peace with them. Other issue is diplomacy where seemingly at random a faction will declare war on you and refuse negotiations for unknown reasons (except for monetary gifts, which they never refuse). You are always fighting on multiple fronts and attrition is killer while you're out of your territory not camped. Still fun, but you're in for the long haul with any campaign. Building becomes a balancing act to ensure squalor, disease, strife, happiness, food, income all match up - which is impossible...more revolts. Also don't build a shipyard on the African East coast (or anywhere that water channels don't lead to the ocean) because inevitably you will be locked in with no way to get out and have to disband your fleet. I won a minor victory but was confused as it says puppet states and alliances count toward the total provinces toward victory, but I feel that it didn't account for my alliances - however it only counts a full province which is three settlements in combination, so maybe that's why. Bless those that can play each faction's campaign and the DLC all the way through, because barely 60 hours into it and I feel burnt out. I have several other TW titles in my library but it will likely be a few months before I delve back into the series.
